masterFinding.verificationInstructions:
Verification Instructions

Run SQL queries (direct SQL or SQL injection) to identify tables and columns that may contain passwords:
  • Oracle: select owner,table_name,column_name from all_tab_columns where column_name like '%PASS%'

  • MSSQL: select table_name,column_name from information_schema.columns where column_name like '%pass%'


Select data from the identified tables to determine if the application stores cleartext passwords in the database.

Reporting Requirements
  1. Show how SQL queries executed

  2. Show query that is used to tables potentially containing cleartext passwords

  3. Show query that is used to select password information

  4. Show cleartext passwords - redact password
masterFinding.remediationInstructions: Do not store clear text passwords. Use a strong hashing method to protect passwords in the database and make sure the hash is salted. When the passwords need to be compared during authentication, the input value will also need to be salted and hashed before they can be compared.
masterFinding.name: Unencrypted Storage of Passwords - Database
masterFinding.businessImpact: Any user with read access to the affected tables in the database may use the credentials in future attacks.  The impact will vary greatly depending on what the credentials are used for, but they may be used to gain unauthorized access to systems, applications, and sensitive information.
masterFinding.description: Passwords are stored in cleartext in the database. An attacker who is able to gain read access to the database will be able to access these passwords.
